title: What purpose does the AVVO free question forum serve? Foreclosures, Real Estate, Business, Bankruptcy, Debt, Family law.
question: I am an avid fan and occasionally read questions and answers for self-education. I have a few observations for attorneys. Almost always, it is recommended that the questioner retain counsel. Understandable caveat but insofar as a question is posed, does this not suggest that (a) there is a lack of money or, (b) one is trying to learn of options before consulting counsel. Secondly, I have on a few occasions noticed that some attorneys could be quite hostile to the questioner. In one instance, an attorney stated that the questioner was trying to get a house free. Really, that gratuitous comment was unwarranted, very rude and insensitive. In a response comment, the questioned indicated he would pose both his question and response on Yelp!. The attorney threatened a defamation suit. Really! Thirdly, I posed a securities question on the forum. One response, and I paraphrase, “no right minded attorney would answer such a question.” In fact, several did – one being particularly thorough. Based on the responses, counsel was retained. While there is no free lunch, the forum exists. You do not have to respond but if you do, be gracious. This is surely appreciated by the questioners. Thanks.
answers:
Thank you for your feedback.

Like society in general, the variety of Avvo-responding attorneys contains a variety from sincere and intelligent to arrogant and mean-spirited. As the era of anonymous social media progresses where people write the most outrageous things they would never dare to say to your face, I am afraid that the dichotomy and phenomenon will grow worse, not better.

Even though your posting contains no legal question, I think it should remain as a communication of value to the Avvo attorneys. I am changing the practice area from Debt Agreements (which I don't think applies) to "General Practice" where I think it will get greater readership. (You can easily change it back if you disagree.)

If someone has a general legal question regarding an area of law, posting it in the AVVO forum is a decent idea. It does not take the place of an actual attorney-client relationship, where the attorney gets to review documents, do research, and ask questions. But it has its place.

What do the lawyers get out of it? Hopefully an opportunity to demonstrate some level of skill or knowledge in an area of law.

It is also unwise to throw all our legal reasoning on a matter which is either pending, or soon to be, onto the publicly searchable internet. I have personally had clients questioned under oath about their social media posts, not Avvo, but it is indeed quite common. Innocent errors in stating the facts can come back to haunt you. Legal advice - meaning advice given as to your specific problem - should not be given in public.

Certainly, threatening a poster with a lawsuit, if not provoked by a threat by the poster, is impolite. However, there are questions asked which are convoluted, which involve considerable financial or even criminal consequences, and, to be blunt, no lawyer should answer them. Maybe the attorney who doesn't answer a question, who protects his own interests, is going to better protect yours as well.

Sometimes the best advice one can be given is to seek counsel. I've been licensed for over twenty years and I've never seen an unrepresented plaintiff succeed on any significant civil lawsuit. I am sure there are some out there, but they are rare.

The legal system is a daunting place for those who don't deal with it all the time, and for those who don't have many years of training, education, and experience. And even for those - one side always loses! That being said, there are no doubt thousands of people out there who do their own dentistry, roofing, car repairs, legal work, and brain surgery, and are quite happy with the results. All kidding aside, as one responder noted, the advice to seek counsel is perhaps the single most important thing one can give to any inquiry about a legal issue of significance.

The forum is meant to be a place to discuss things, but not to offer legal advice. Some lawyers read the question and see nothing but a can of worms they don't want to open. I agree they do not need to chime in if they have nothing to offer. Hostility is a bad practice period, but sometimes the attorney has a time pressure to respond and fails to act appropriately. I for one never say "get an attorney" without offering some perspective or useful comment. I hope many people read your question because it offers some good perspective to attorneys.

The simple fact of the matter is this - in many, many of the questions posed throughout the forums, the suggestion to retain counsel is one of the most important tidbits of information to be shared. The forums are not a place to piecemeal free advice, offering up snippets of information and then acting on responses as those snippets out and snippets returned comprise a full puzzle.

To not point out to someone that their matter is important, perhaps winnable, if they decide to find a way to commit to the need for counsel rather than hope someone can offer up enough information to let them wing it and hope for a favorable result.

I am going to swim upstream a bit, because I'd like to, and observe it in a forum like this the question asker ought not be telling the lawyers how to frame their responses.

Being "gracious" just for the sake of it may communicate a message that is inappropriate where question askers of varying degrees of education, varying degrees of economic sophistication, and intelligence, that can be a mistake. An outlier on the distribution curve just like being hostile or sarcastic is.

The practice of law is difficult and various cautions must be observed in responding to people you don't represent. There are nightmare stories of people who thought a kind word from an attorney was legal advice. If the matter is complex I always suggest they sit with counsel.
